Thomas J. Watson Sr. was leader of IBMâ€”carrying at various times the titles of general manager, CEO, president, and chairmanâ€”from 1914 to 1956. During this period, the company became a major player in the American and international data processing industries, setting the stage for its dominance of computing in the decades that followed.

Watson is a controversial figure principally because of IBMâ€™s relationship with the government of Nazi Germany. The history of this relationship, and of Watsonâ€™s role in it, is complex. It is the subject of a bestselling 2001 book, IBM and the Holocaust, by journalist Edwin Black. Unfortunately, IBM and the Holocaust is generally regarded as hyperbolic and inaccurate by historians who research related subjects.
